answer: No, I'm not saying you're lying. I'm saying you accidentally forgot that what you first said was five hundred.

question: I don't do anything accidentally, jerk. I might've first said five hundred, but what I last said was three hundred, and what you say last is what counts.
answer: Well then, if you say five hundred one last time, we got a deal.

question: You fuckin' with me, Pendejo?
answer: No, not at all. It's New Year's Eve and I'm here alone. If there was somebody else here, no problem, but I'm by myself. And looking after your kids is a pain in the ass I don't need --

question: You callin' my kids a pain in the ass?
answer: -- No, they're not a pain in the ass, it's the situation that's a pain in the ass.

question: Okay. These are the rules. Don't break the rules and I won't break your necks. I always wanted to say that. Someone said that to me when I was a kid. Except they were joking. I'm not. The rules are simple. Don't do anything you wouldn't do if your parents were here. If there's an emergency, call me on the phone, like your dad said.
answer: That's not what he said. He said to call if we need anything.

question: Well, I've got a lot of work to do and I can't have you calling me every time you want a drink of water, so please limit your calls to emergencies only.
answer: We paid you five hundred dollars. We'll call you if we need anything. You don't want to upset my dad.

question: Your feet stink.
answer: They don't stink. Check it out. T & A.

question: Change it. You're not supposed to watch this.
answer: We're supposed to watch TV.

question: Ted? Hi. It's me, Sarah. You're our sitter for tonight.
answer: Oh, Jesus, what did I tell you? I said if you don't bother me, you'll get milk and cookies. Now, do you want them or do you not?

question: I want you to turn off the Nudie station in our room.
answer: I can't turn on an adult station without permission from your parents.

question: No. Not turn it on, turn it off. It's already on.
answer: That's not what the machine tells me.

question: Well, stop listening to the machine and listen to me. There's naked ladies dancing on my TV and I want 'em off.
answer: If you're good, you'll get milk and cookies, so leave me alone, please. I'll be up later to put you both to sleep.

question: Change the channel, now!
answer: Man, you're the one with the stinky feet.

question: They don't stink.
answer: Yeah, they do.

question: Here, smell for yourself. Go ahead.
answer: Hey, get a bottle opener!

question: Don't shake it! Ted? Hi. It's me. Sarah.
answer: Yeah. Who died? No one? Then don't call me.

question: I thought I'd tell you that your cleaning ladies are doing a bum job. There's all kinds of leftover stuff around here. Needles and things. We're not supposed to have needles here, are we? I mean, they don't come with the room, do they? Send someone up here to clean this place up right. I TOLD YOU NOT TO SHAKE IT! I gotta go. My brother just exploded the champagne all over the room. Oh, and bring us a couple of toothbrushes. There's a card in the bathroom that says you'll bring free toothbrushes if we ask for them. I'm calling another room, give me three numbers. Hello? Hi. You don't know me, and I don't know you, but... do you have any needles? We've got needles here and I was wondering if they come with the room or not. Don't have any? Thanks. Just checking. The center is the bull's eye, 100 points, this one's 10 points, this one's 20 points. Hey, wait a minute. Let me get out of the way!
answer: I brought you some milk and cookies. If you want some you have to eat them now, because you're going to sleep.

question: We're going to sleep now?
answer: Your parents said put you to bed before midnight. Well, it's before midnight. Maybe that way you'll leave me alone.

question: Those aren't milk and cookies.
answer: We were out of cookies, so I brought you milk and Saltines. Don't complain! Now hurry up and eat. You're going to bed right now.

question: Yep. If you wanna watch too, you have to go wash your face. Be careful... Ted!
answer: What do you want now, for Christ's sake! Who died?

question: I don't know, but she's in my bed!
answer: What?

question: There's a dead body in my bed!
answer: That's just your brother. Sound asleep.

question: No, there's a woman's dead body inside the bed, in the mattress.
answer: You saw the body?

question: Yes!
answer: Impossible. You've got ointment on your eyes! You can't see shit! Now go to sleep! Godammit, go to sleep!

question: I washed it off...
answer: You washed off the ointment?

question: Yeah, didn't you ever think to do that? You never tried it, did you? Then you agree I'm smarter than you...
answer: All right. Now you listen to me...

question: I'm coming up and if there isn't a dead body by the time I get there, I'll make one myself. You! Oh shit! What the fuck is going on??!! Your parents are on their way up and I'm not taking responsibility for this mess!
answer: Check under the mattress!

question: For what?
answer: For the body, can't you smell it?

question: It's your feet! Jesus fucking Christ! What the fuck is this? Police, it's an emergency! Hello, Police, this is the Mon Signor Hotel, get someone up here right fucking now, there's a DEAD WHORE stuffed under the mattress!
answer: Don't call her that...

question: I'm dead fucking serious, there's a dead fucking Whore stuffed in the bedsprings of the fucking bed!
answer: Stop calling her that!!

question: Happy New Year!
answer: Let me speak to Betty.

question: Party's over, she probably went home.
answer: She lives there.

question: Oh, well, I haven't seen 'em in a while.
answer: Do you even know who I'm talking about?

question: Yeah... yeah... yeah... I know 'em, I know Eddy.
answer: Betty, not Eddy.

question: Yeah... yeah... I know Betty too... Tall...
answer: No, not particularly. She's got curly red hair.

question: No, no, no, no, no, I know, I know. Japanese girl.
answer: She's not Japanese! I just said she had red hair.

question: Yeah... yeah... yeah... I know her.
answer: Well, then get her on the phone, it's an emergency.

question: Who -- who should I say's calling?
answer: Tell 'em Teddy from work's on the phone, and it's a major fuckin' emergency.

question: Gotcha, Betty from work.
answer: Not Betty from work, I'm calling Betty! I'm Teddy. Just say Ted.

question: Hi, Ted, I'm Margaret. You sound down. Has this not been the happiest of New Year's?
answer: No Margaret, this hasn't been my best New Year. This year's starting off pretty badly.

question: No Margaret, this hasn't been my best New Year. This year's starting off pretty badly.
answer: Awww, how come?

question: Well, Betty -- the chick whose house you're at, even though you don't know her -- leaves me here all by myself on New Year's Eve. And first thing right off the bat, I'm fucked by a coven of witches.
answer: An oven full of witches fucked you? Is that like at the circus when they stick all those clowns in an itty- bitty car?

question: A coven. A coven of witches. Well, one witch in particular.
answer: Was she an old hag with a mole, with hair growing out of it?

question: No-no-no, she was... quite beautiful.
answer: Ted?

question: Yes.
answer: What's the problem?

question: Well, admittedly, that was the best part of the night. It was pretty fuckin' cool, actually. But it was still an unnerving way to start off the night.
answer: Sounds to me like a pretty great way to start off the night.

question: Okay, let's just skip over the witches.
answer: -- Skipping over the witches.

question: So, later, in another room, some crazy sucking maniac sticks a gun in my face and forces me to play out some psychosexual drama with his wife.
answer: He made you have psycho sex with his wife?

question: No, he didn't make me fuck his wife, he thought I'd fucked his wife! He held me at gunpoint with a loaded gun!
answer: What kinda gun?

question: I don't know, I'm not a gun guy. It was big.
answer: Like Dirty Harry's gun.

question: Yeah, something like that.
answer: Did it have a real long barrel or a short barrel?

question: What difference does it make?
answer: Well, for one thing it's the difference between a .44 Magnum and a Magnum .357.

question: Who cares if it was a .44 or a .392, it was a fuckin' loaded gun, pointed at my fuckin' head!
answer: You wanna skip over this part, too?

question: I want you to get Betty on the phone!
answer: Hold on. Anybody live here named... What's her name again?

question: Betty.
answer: Betty!

question: Betty!
answer: Yeah, whatcha screamin' about?

question: You're Betty?
answer: Yeah, I'm Betty, it's my fuckin' place, who the fuck are you?

question: I'm Margaret And this is Ted.
answer: Ted, what's the problem?

question: Ted, what's the problem?
answer: What's the problem? I don't got a problem, I got fuckin' problems! Wanna hear?

question: Sure.
answer: Well, most recently, there's room 716. There's a scary Mexican gangster dude pokin' his finger in my chest. There's his hooligan kids snapping their fingers at me. There's the putrid rotting corpse of a dead whore stuffed in the springs of a bed. There're rooms blazing afire... There's a needle from God knows where stuck in my leg, infecting me with God knows what, and finally, there's me walking out the fuckin' door right now! Buenas noches.

question: Is that the penthouse?
answer: Yeah.

question: That's the Chester Rush party, they want something.
answer: Yeah, well, tough titty. They're just gonna have to wait, 'cause I'm out the door.

question: Now, Ted, wait a minute. I know you're freaked, I know you're stressed. You've had a real bad night --
answer: Yes, Betty, I've had-a-real-bad-night --

question: -- You say there's a dead body in a room?
answer: Yes, I did.

question: No problem, this is a hotel, we've had dead bodies before, it's just the price of doing business. You said the hotel was on fire. Is it still on fire?
answer: No, it's out.

question: Good, sprinkler system worked like a charm. Now, you wanna leave, you've had enough. Perfectly understandable. I'll take care of everything else. The only thing I ask is that you take care of Chester Rush. Then you can leave.
answer: Now, look --

question: Ted, he's a very important guest of this hotel. In fact, he is the most important guest at the hotel. The Mon Signor used to be a haven for movie stars. Through the thirties and forties, and the first half of the fifties, more movie stars -- if you break it down on a night-by-night basis -- stayed at the Mon Signor than any other hotel in Hollywood. Now, we had some hard time in the eighties, even though we were the official hotel of Cannon Pictures, but we're coming back strong in the nineties. And a movie star clientele is important to that comeback. If we can keep stars of his magnitude happy, we're on our way. So, Ted, just take care of him, then you can leave.
answer: Look, I don't feel like --

question: He probably just wants some champagne! You can do that, can't you? Please just take care of him, the entire staff of the Mon Signor is begging you!
answer: Okay. But get your ass here pronto.

question: You're a good man, Ted. Thanks.
answer: Hello, Mr. Rush. Sorry for the delay. How can I help you?

question: Hello, Mr. Rush. Sorry for the delay. How can I help you?
answer: Hi, Theodore.

question: What the hell are you doing here?
answer: Having a drink.

question: Is that crazy husband of yours in there?
answer: Are you kidding, he'll be asleep till Christmas.

question: Actually, it's not Theodore, It's Ted.
answer: So, Ted the Bellboy, as I was saying -- would you care for some champagne? That's not what I was saying, but would you care for some champagne?

question: No, thank you.
answer: Ya sure? Cristal. It's the best. I never liked champagne before I had Cristal, now I love it.

question: Okay, yeah, sure.
answer: -- As I was saying, Ted, don't worry about being late. For our purposes, promptness is far behind thoroughness. Chin-chin. Whadya say, Ted?

question: Thank you?
answer: No, not thank you. Whadya say about the tasty beverage?

question: It's good.
answer: Fuckin' good, Ted. It's fuckin' good. Let's try it again, shall we? So, Ted, whadya think about the beverage.

question: It's fuckin' good.
answer: You bet your sweet bippy, Ted. It's fuckin' Cristal, everything else is piss.

question: Knock it off, you're making my friend Ted here uneasy. Pay no attention to Norman here, Ted, he's just fuckin' wit' ya, that's all. That's from Quadrophenia. Now me, myself, when I think of bellboys I think of -- "bellboy" isn't an insult, is it? Is there another name for what you do that I'm ignorant of? Bellman, bellperson --
answer: Bellboy's fine.

question: Good. I'm glad they haven't changed that. There's a friendliness to "bellboy." As I was saying, Ted, when Norman thinks of bellboys, he thinks of Quadrophenia.
answer: No.

question: You should, it's one of Jerry's better movies. He never says a word through the entire film. A completely silent performance. How many actors can pull that off? And he has to go to France to get respect. That says it all about America right there. The minute Jerry Lewis dies, every paper in this fuckin' country gonna write articles calling the man a genius. It's not right. It's not right and it's not fair. But why should that surprise anybody? When has America ever been fair? We might be right every once in a while, but we're very rarely fair.
answer: Where do you want this?

question: You in a hurry, Ted?
answer: No, not particularly.

question: I'm cool, so talk to your wife. 72.1 million dollars. That's before video and before foreign, and before pay-TV and before free TV. We're talking fuckin' asses in fuckin' seats. Before all that other shit, The Wacky Detective made 72.1 million dollars. And my new one, The Dog Catcher, it's projected to break a hundred. The Dog Catcher.
answer: The Dog Catcher.

question: Now let's stroll over here and see what goodies you brought us.
answer: Do you mind me asking what's all this stuff for?

question: That's how many Peter Lorre asked for. Continue, Ted.
answer: A roll of twine.

question: That's definitely a roll of twine. Continue.
answer: A bucket of ice.

question: Go on.
answer: A donut.

question: That's for me. Continue.
answer: And a hatchet.

question: A hatchet as sharp as the devil himself is what I asked for.
answer: Well, you be the judge.

question: Well, that's everything, so if you don't need me for anything else, I'll go back downstairs.
answer: Not so fast, Ted. We ain't quite done yet. Why don't you take a seat at the bar, get comfortable, and have an open mind when we explain the festivities of the evening to you.

question: Look, guys, you paid for the room. As long as you don't break up the furniture, you can do whatever the fuck you want. And me personally, I don't care if you break up the furniture. You don't have to explain anything to me. Whatever constitutes a good time as far as you guys are concerned is your business.
answer: Well, it's your business, Ted. 'Cause we want you to take part.

question: Look at the poor guy. Just spit it out.
answer: First off, let me say that there's nothing homosexual about what we're going to ask you to do. There's nothing sexual at all about what we want. But I was thinkin' you might be thinkin' we want you to do some sex thing. Pee on us, suck us off, shit like that. Let me assure you nothing could be farther from what we want --

question: Can I jump in here?
answer: No, you can't jump in here, this is my story.

question: Theodore's been here fifteen minutes and you've talked about everything but.
answer: Hey, if you don't like it, you can get the fuck out.

question: Thank you. Ted, did you ever watch the old "Alfred Hitchcock Show"?
answer: Yeah.

question: Did you ever see the episode The Man from Rio, with Peter Lorre and Steve McQueen?
answer: I don't think so.

question: Oh, you'd remember it all right. In the show, Peter Lorre makes a bet that Steve McQueen can't light his cigarette lighter ten times in a row. Now if Steve McQueen can light his cigarette lighter ten times in a row, he wins Peter Lorre's new car. If he can't he loses his little finger. Norman and Chester just made the same bet. Norman's putting up his pinky against Chester's mint convertible, 1964 red convertible Chevy Corvelle that he can light his Zippo ten times in a row.
answer: You guys are drunk.
